description: From a South Slavic language, from Turkish kule, from Persian قله‎ (qolle), from Arabic قُلَّة‎ (qulla, “pinnacle, zenith”).

entries.meaning: A tower, turret or steeple on the Balkans erected during the period of Ottoman domination on the area.
examples: Instead of the haïdooks, their next of kin, the zaptiés now hold a kula on the highest point of the pass; here one pauses to rest after scrambling up the vile Turkish road on one side of the ravine, and before scrambling down the vile Turkish road on the other.

entries.meaning: A ceremonial exchange system conducted in the Milne Bay Province of Papua New Guinea, involving the exchange of bracelets and necklaces, and linked to political authority.
